feed.title: Combined summary - DPL is not only not enough, but brings unfounded confidence to Bitcoin users

entry.title: Combined summary - DPL is not only not enough, but brings unfounded confidence to Bitcoin users
entry.summary: The conversation on the bitcoin-dev mailing list centered around the role of patents in the technology industry and its effect on Bitcoin users. The rejection of a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) that benefits the ASICBOOST patent without disclosure has made the network less secure, according to one individual who denies the accusation and proposes a community crowdfund to license the technology.Defensive Patent License (DPL) v1.1 has been criticized for being dangerous for Bitcoin users as it allows companies to enforce their patents against anyone who has not joined. A dedicated Bitcoin-related defensive patent pool, similar to Linux's Open Invention Network, could be more effective in encouraging cooperation and punishing aggressors. Changing the Bitcoin Core license to something like an Apache2/LGPL3 dual license could ensure the copyright license also has anti-patent protections.One user suggests granting everyone an irrevocable license for the content of emails or BIPs, while another argues that pledging not to use patents offensively defeats the point of owning patents. The discussion highlights the complex issue of patents in the technology industry and the need for careful consideration when obtaining and utilizing them. Several people have noted that patent applications are more effective than defensive publication at getting prior art under the noses of patent examiners. There were also concerns expressed about the DPL v1.1 and how it may pose a threat to Bitcoin users. The Defensive Patent License (DPL) v1.1 was criticized by some for being dangerous for Bitcoin users as it allows companies that join DPL to enforce their patents against anyone who has not joined, which could lead to new Bitcoin users being forced to pay royalties.The benefits of using the Apache 2.0 license, which contains an explicit patent license grant and terminates that license if the licensee asserts a claim alleging that the covered work infringes a patent, were also highlighted. The conversation touched on a proposal made by an individual for a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) that had the effect of benefiting their ASICBOOST patent without disclosing it. The ASICBOOST patent, according to the individual, protects Bitcoiners from mining centralization, but they have no control over the company that owns the technology.
